overextraction_cases.case_text:
(CA IRB)

IAD File No. / N° de dossier de la SAI : VA9-03559 / 60 / 61 / 62

1 REASONS FOR DECISION

[1] These are the reasons for the decisions in the appeals of [REDACTED] [VA9-03559], [REDACTED] [VA9-03560], [REDACTED] [VA9-03561], and [REDACTED] [VA9- 03562] (the appellants) from removal orders made against them on June 17, 2009 by the Immigration Division (the ID) of the Immigr ation and Refugee Board. The ID issued the removal orders on the ground that [REDACTED] was a person described in subsection 41(b) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (the Act).

1 In particular, he did not comply with the conditions imposed on his as required by subsection 27(2) of the Act. The other appellants were accompanying family members of [REDACTED] and hence are also inadmissible due to his failure to comply. ISSUE [2] The appellants do not challenge to the legal validity of the removal orders and, based on the evidence before me, I am satisfied that the re moval orders are valid in law. The issue before the panel is whether the appeals should be allowed on the basis that sufficient humanitarian and compassionate considerations warrant special relief in light of all the circumstances of the cases, taking into account the best interests of any child directly affected by the decision. [3] The appellants became permanent resident under the provisions of the former Immigration Act (the former Act)

2 and subparagraphs 23(1)(i)(a) through (d) of the former Immigration Regulations (the former Regulations).

3 These appeals are being determined in accordance with the transitional provisions of the Act. DECISION [REDACTED] [VA9-03559] [4] I have come to the conclusion that the removal order is valid in law and that there are not sufficient humanitarian and compassionate grounds, in light of all the circumstances of the case,



1 Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, S.C. 2001, c. 27.

2 Immigration Act, R.S.C. 1985, c.I-2 as amended.

3 Immigration Regulations, 1...

overextraction_cases.case_text:
(CA IRB)

RAD File / Dossier de la SAR : TB8 -26704

TB8 -26705 / TB8 -26706 / TB8 -26707



RAD.25.02 ( January , 20 20)

Disponible en français 2

REASONS FOR DECISION

OVERVIEW

[1] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] (Principal A ppellant) , and her children [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] (Associate

Appellant), [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] and [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] (Minor Associate Appellants),

appeal a decision of the Refugee Protection Division (RPD), dated September 14, 2018 , rejecting

their claims for refugee protection.

[2] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] and her son [REDACTED] are citizens of Kazakhstan.

[REDACTED] and [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] are citizens of Pakistan.

[3] The principal Appellant acted as the Designated Representative for the Minor Associate

Appellants, [REDACTED] and [REDACTED] .

[4] The Appellants submit that the RPD erred in law in its analysis on credibility, state

protection and review of the Appellants’ forward -look ing risk. The Appellants ask the Refugee

Appeal Division (RAD) to overturn the RP D’s decision and either substitute a finding that they

are Convention refugees or persons in need of protection.

DETERMINATION OF THE APPEAL

[5] This is a split decision with respect to the Appellants’ appeals.

[6] With respect to [REDACTED] [REDACTED] and [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] , citizens of Kazakhstan,

their appeal is dismissed. Pursuant to paragraph 111(1)( a) of the Immigration and Refugee

Protection Act (the “ Act ”), the RAD confirms the decision of the RPD that the Appellants are

neither Convention refugees nor persons in need of protection and dismisses the appeal.

[7] With respect to [REDACTED] and [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] , citizens of Pakistan, their

appeal is allowed. Pursuant to paragraph 111(1)( b) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection

Act (the “Act” ), the RAD sets aside the determination of the RPD and substitutes its own

determination that the App...

overextraction_cases.case_text:
(CA IRB)

RAD F ile No. / N° de dossier de la SA R : TB7 -20771

TB7 -20772

TB7 -20773



REASONS FOR DECISION

[1] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] (the “Principal Appellant”), [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED]

[REDACTED] (the “Spousal Appellant”) and [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] (the “Minor Appellant”) are

citizens of Nigeria and are appealing a dec ision of the Refugee Protection Division (RPD)

denying their claims for refugee protection.

[2] The Minor Appellant is the daughter of the Principal Appellant and Spousal Appellant.

The Principal and Spousal Appellants also have a son named [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED]

[REDACTED] , who was born in Canada and is a Canadian citizen and not an Appellant in this case . The

Principal Appellant was named as the Designated Representative (DR) of the Minor Appellant at

the RPD hearing and the RAD confirms this designation.

[3] The Appellan ts are requesting that the Refugee Appeal Division (RAD) set aside the

RPD’s negative determination and find that they are Convention refugees or persons in need of

protection. In the alternative, the Appellants request that the RAD refer the matters back to the

RPD for redetermination by a differently constituted panel.

RAD DETERMINATION

[4] In relation to the Minor Appellant, pursuant to s.111(1)( b) of the Immigration and Refugee

Protection Act (IRPA),1 the RAD sets aside the determination of the RPD and subs titutes its own

determination that the Minor Appellant is a Convention refugee. This appeal is allowed.

[5] In relation to the Principal and Spousal Appellants, the RAD dismisses the appeal and

confirms the decision of the RPD that the Principal and Spousal Ap pellants are neither

Convention refugees nor persons in need of protection pursuant to s.111(1)( a) of the IRPA.2





1 S.111(1)( b), Immigration and Refugee Protection Act , S.C. 2001, c.27. [ IRPA ]

2 S.111(1)( a), Immigration and Refugee Protection Act ...

overextraction_cases.case_text:
(CA IRB)

RAD Fil e No. / N ° de dossier de la SAR : VB5 -02292







REASONS FOR DECISION



[1] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] (the “appellant”), a national of Ethiopia , appeals a decision of the

Refugee Protection Division (the “RPD”) rejecting her claim for refugee protection.



DETERMINATION OF THE AP PEAL



[2] Pursuant to paragraph 111(1)(c) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (the

“Act ”),1 the Refugee Appeal Division (the “ RAD ”) orders that the determination of the RPD that

the appellant is neither a Convention refugee nor a person in need of pr otection be set aside and

that the matter be returned to the RPD for redetermination by a different RPD Member without

further instruction. The appeal is allowed.



BACKGROUND



[3] In her claim for refugee protection, the appellant alleged that she and her Cana dian born

daughter would be persecuted by her parents in law if they were to return to Ethiopia. The

appellant alleged that her husband’s family insists that her daughter be circumcised. The

appellant refuses to allow this. However, while her husband is al so opposed to his daughter’s

circumcision, he is allegedly unable to oppose his parents out of respect for tradition.



[4] The appellant alleged that the threat of her daughter’s circumcision represents a form of

persecution as she fears that her refusal to a llow this and to have stayed in Canada without her

in-laws permission will result in severe punishment for her. She also alleged that the prospect of

circumcision for her Canadian born daughter represents a form of psychological persecution for

her .



1 Immigration and Refugee Protect ion Act (the “ Act ”), S.C. 2001, c. 27.

2015 CanLII 111161 (CA IRB)

RAD File No. / N° de dossier de la SAR : VB5 -02992









[5] The RPD heard the appellant’s refugee protection claim on April 10, 2015 . The RPD’s

reasons for the decision were rendered in writing with a Notice of Decision dated May 12, 2015 .

The RPD’s reason...

overextraction_cases.case_text:
(CA IRB)

IAD File No. / No de dossier de la SAI : TA9 -19424

Client ID No. / No ID client : 4076 -7411



1

Rea sons for Decision



Introduction

[1] The respondent makes an application that the appeal be dismissed for lack of jurisdiction.

The appeal is pursuant to sub section 63(3) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act1

(IRPA ) of a removal order made against the appellant.

Decision

[2] Having considered the evidence and submissions, the panel finds that the appeal is

dismissed .

Background

[3] The Immigration Division issued a deportatio n order in September 2009 against the

appellant based on paragraph 36(1)( a) of the IRPA ,2 and the appellant appealed that order.

[4] In September 2012, the respondent made an application to dismiss the appeal for absence

of jurisdiction. On September 27, 2012, the appellant was requested to make any submissions;

none were received. This matter w as dealt with in chambers.

Analysis

[5] A person may be inadmissible based on serious criminality:3

36. (1) A permanent resident or a foreign national is inadmissible on grounds of

serious criminality for

(a) having been convicted in Canada of an offence under an Act of Parliament

punishable by a maximum term of imprisonment of at least 10 years, or of an

offence under an Act of Parliament for which a term of imprisonment of more than

six months has been imposed;



1 Immigration and Refugee Protection Act , S.C. 2001, c. 27.

2 Record, p. 29.

3 Immigration and Refugee Protection Act , S.C. 2001, c. 27.

2012 CanLII 101335 (CA IRB)

IAD File No. / No de dossier de la SAI : TA9 -19424

Client ID No. / No ID client : 4076 -7411



2 [6] Additionally, a removal order may be stayed and the appeal may be terminated:

68. (1) To stay a removal order, the Immigration Appeal Division must be satisfied,

taking into account the best interests of a child directly affected by the decision, that

sufficient humanitarian and compassionate considerat ions warrant speci...

that it is manifestly unfounded this appeal is allowed background 3 the respondent xxxxxxxxxxxxxx alleged before the rpd that he is a gay man

come to an independent assessment of whether the claimant is a convention refugee or a person in need of protection where its assessment departs from that of the rpd the rad must substitute its own decision 55 in conducting its assessm ent it can recognize
none by the respondent i find that on a balance of probabilities the identity of the respondent has not been established therefore the rad substitutes the determination that should have bee n made

immigration 2007 fc 1292 2007 f cj no 166 ql at para 3 2015 canlii 105868 ca irb rad f ile no n de dossier de la sa r conclusion 55 for all these reasons due to the evidence on the appeal record the rad sets aside the determination of the rpd

the rpd there was no credible or trustworthy evidence o n which a favourable decision could have been made 56 section 107 1 of irpa provides that the rpd shall make a finding of no credible basis if it determines that there was no credible or trustworthy evidence on which it could have made a favourable decisio n 57 nothing in irpa expressly gives the rad the authority to make a finding of no credible basis in the panel s view however such jurisdiction is implicit in section 111 1 b which empowers the rad to set aside the determination of the rpd

come to an independent assessment of whether the claimant is a convention refugee or a person in need of protection where its assessment departs from that of the rpd the rad must substitute its own decision 55 in conducting its assessm ent it can recognize
none by the respondent i find that on a balance of probabilities the identity of the respondent has not been established therefore the rad substitutes the determination that should have bee n made

immigration 2007 fc 1292 2007 f cj no 166 ql at para 3 2015 canlii 105868 ca irb rad f ile no n de dossier de la sa r conclusion 55 for all these reasons due to the evidence on the appeal record the rad sets aside the determination of the rpd

the rpd there was no credible or trustworthy evidence o n which a favourable decision could have been made 56 section 107 1 of irpa provides that the rpd shall make a finding of no credible basis if it determines that there was no credible or trustworthy evidence on which it could have made a favourable decisio n 57 nothing in irpa expressly gives the rad the authority to make a finding of no credible basis in the panel s view however such jurisdiction is implicit in section 111 1 b which empowers the rad to set aside the determination of the rpd

overextraction_cases.case_text:
(CA IRB)







2015 CanLII 105868 (CA IRB)

RAD F ile No. / N° de dossier de la SA R :

REASONS FOR DECISION

[1] The Minister of Citizenship and Immigration Canada (the Appellant) appeals a decision of

the Refugee Protection Division (RPD) accepting the claim for refugee protection of [REDACTED]

[REDACTED] [REDACTED] (the Respondent ), a male from Nigeria. The Minister has submitted new evidence

in support of the appeal that was not presented at the RPD hearing.

DETERMINATION OF THE APPEAL

[2] Pursuant to ss. 111 (1) (b) of Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA ), the

Refugee Appeal Division ( RAD ) sets aside the determination of the RPD and substitutes the

determination that [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] is neith er a Convention refugee pursuant to s. 96 of the

IRPA nor a person in need of protection pursuant to s. 97 of IRPA. Pursuant to ss. 107(2) of

IRPA, the RAD finds that there is no credible basis for the claim and that it is manifestly

unfounded. This Appeal is allowed.

BACKGROUND

[3] The Respondent, [REDACTED] , alleged before the RPD that he is a gay man and

was involved in a sexual relationship with another man. The Respondent in the Addendum to his

Basis of Claim form (BOC) states that he engaged in a he terosexual relationship with one other

person of the opposite sex in Nigeria in an attempt to camouflage his true sexual orientation.

[4] The Respondent alleges that on [REDACTED] [REDACTED] , 2013 while he was going home, he was

stopped by an unknown person who advised [REDACTED] not to go home, as there was police looking for

him, and that there had been a killing in the neighbourhood. The unknown person told the

Respondent to hide; the Respondent later learnt that the person killed was his fiancé, [REDACTED] . The

Respondent alleges that the assailants were either police officers or individuals purported to be

the same.

[5] The Respondent further alleges that this unknown man took him to a restaurant where he

left t...

overextraction_cases.case_text:
(CA IRB)

RAD F ile No. / N° de dossier de la SA R :

REASONS FOR DECISION

[1] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] (the Appellant), a citizen of Somalia, appeals a decision of the

Refugee Protection Division (RPD) denying her claim for refugee protection. She has submitted

new evidence in support of her appeal and further seeks to submit additional evidence, not

previously provided, under Rule 29 of the RPD Rules . The Appellant asks the Refugee Appeal

Division (RAD) to set aside the decision of the RPD and refer the matter back to the RPD for re -

determination; or set aside the determination of the RPD and sub stitute that determination with a

determination that the Appellant is a Convention refugee or a person in need of protection; or in

the event that the RAD raises a serious issue respecting the Appellant's credibility or that of her

newly submitted evidence , hold a hearing in accordance to section 110(6) of the Immigration and

Refugee Protection Act (IRPA).

[2] As the Appellant had submitted some of her evidence beyond the date of perfection of the

appeal, a notice was sent to the Minister on August 14 advising the Minister that he has until

August 21 to make submissions on the request of the Appellant. The Minister, as to the date of

completion of this document , has not responded.

DETERMINATION

[3] Pursuant to Section 111(1)(b) of the IRPA , the RAD sets aside the determination of the

RPD and substitutes its determination that the Appellant is a Convention refugee.

Background

[4] The Appellant alleged before the RPD that she was born in [REDACTED] , Somalia. She is a

member of the [REDACTED] Clan. Her parents were from [REDACTED] , having relocated to [REDACTED] during

the Somali civil war. The Appellant lived her life in an area of [REDACTED] known as " [REDACTED] ." She

worked selling produce with her mother until she married [REDACTED] . After the

marriage, she began working in her husband's sma ll shop. On [REDACTED] [REDACTED] , 20...

overextraction_cases.case_text:
(CA IRB)

IAD File No. / N° de dossier de la S AI : MB7 -17896





2

REASONS FOR DECISION



INTRODUCTION

[1] These are the reasons for the decision in the appeal of [REDACTED] (the

appellant) from a removal order made against him on September 26 , 2017 , because of his failure

to comply with the residency obligation set out in the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act1

(the Act ).

[2] Section 28 of the Act requires a permanent resident to be physically present in Canada for

at least 730 days in the five -year period immediately prior to an assessment, which in this case

five years after the appellant’s landing date of June 15, 2014.

[3] The appellant does not challenge the legal validity of the removal order but argues that

the appeal should b e allowed on the basis that sufficient humanitarian and compassionate

considerations warrant special relief, in light of all the circumstances of the case, taking into

account the best interests of any child directly affected by the decision.

[4] I have consi dered the testimony of the appellant, his daughter and his friend, the Appeal

Record and the documents filed by the appellant2 and the respondent’s and the written

submissions3 of the respondent who participated to the appeal with written submissions.

DECI SION

[5] The appellant did not dispute the legal validity of the breach of the residency obligation.

The appellant, at the time of the control had been present in Canada for 66 days during the

relevant five -year period. If he had stayed in Canada after the dat e of the control and the removal



1 Immigration and Refugee Protection Act , S.C. (2001), chap. 27, as amended.

2 Exhibits A -1 to A-3.

3 Appeal Record and Exhibits R -1 to R -5.

2018 CanLII 138816 (CA IRB)

IAD File No. / N° de dossier de la S AI : MB7 -17896





3 order, he could have accumulated a maximum of 627 days. The removal order is valid in law,

and there are not sufficient humanitarian and compassionate grounds, in light of...

overextraction_cases.case_text:
(CA IRB)

RAD File No. / N° de dossier de la S AR :



REASONS FOR DECISION

[1] [REDACTED] (the Appellant), a citizen of Ghana, appeals a decision of the Refugee

Protection Division (RPD) rejecting her claim for refugee protection.

[2] The Appellant submit ted documents to be considered as new evidence pursuant to

s.110(4) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (the Act or IRPA) in support of her

appeal. However, the Appellant did not request a hearing before the Refugee Appeal Division

(RAD) pursuant to section 1 10 (6) of the Act.

[3] The Appellant requests that the RAD set aside the RPD’s decision and remit the matter

back to the RPD for redetermination. In the alternative, the Appellant requests that the RAD grant

any other order that the Division deems reasona ble and expedient having regard to the peculiar

facts and circumstances of this case.

DETERMINATION

[4] Pursuant to Section 111(a) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), the

RAD confirms the decision of the RPD that the Appellant is neithe r a Convention refugee (CR)

nor a person in need of protection pursuant to sections 96 and 97(1) of the IRPA.

[5] This appeal is dismissed.

Background:

[6] The Appellant alleged before the RPD that her husband’s famil y members want to carry

out female circumcision (female genital mutilation) on her infant daughter who was born in

Canada on [REDACTED], 2014. [REDACTED] and her husband oppose this practice. The Appellant is

afraid that she would personally face serious harm, torture or death due to her op posi tion to this

practice. The A ppellant’s husband remains in Ghana and he does not believe that he could protect

his wife or daughter in these circumstances. The Appellant also alleged that all female family

members of her husband have undergone this procedur e and her father -in-law in particular wishes

to preserve this custom .

2015 CanLII 34097 (CA IRB)

RAD File No. / N° de dossier de la S AR :



[7] The Appellant i...

daughter in law confirmed that if this appeal is dismissed he will investigate sponsoring his mother for these reasons i do not accept that the appellant will suffer the hardship of being left alone in hong kong this does not attract special relief 29 i acknowledge the position of the minister that if this appeal is dismissed the appellant can visit her family in canada or potentially be sponsored as a member of the family class 21 however i accept the position of the appellant s counsel that a visa is a poor substitute for pr status l ong distance travel is difficult

overextraction_cases.case_text:
(CA IRB)

IAD File No. / No de dossier de la SAI: TC1-02416

Client ID No. / No ID client: 29405339



REASONS FOR DECISION

OVERVIEW



[1] The Appellant, [REDACTED], is a widowed 73 -year -old British national overseas and

a Chinese citizen who lives in Hong Kong.1 She appeal s a February 2021 decisio n that she did not

compl y with the residency obligation as a permanent resident (PR) .2

[2] To comply with the residency obligation, a PR must be physically present in Canada for

730 days in a five -year period.3 The Appellant concedes that she was present in Canada for zero

days in the relevant five -year period. As such, the validity of the decision is not in dispute.

[3] The issue in this appeal is whether humanitarian and compassionate ( H&C ) considerations

warrant special relief in the Appellant’s case.4 I find that they do. The appeal is allowed.

[4] In 1994, the [REDACTED] landed in Canada with her spouse and their two children.5 Their

son stayed in Canada with the [REDACTED]’s brother. The Appellant, her spouse, and t heir daughter

returned to Hong Kong. They intended to settle permanently in Canada in 1995 or 1996 after

winding up her spouse’s business in Hong Kong. The Appellant, her spouse, and their daughter

returned to Canada in 1995 to visit their son. The [REDACTED] nt’s spouse experienced health concerns

during those long -haul flights. Consequently, he refused to travel anywhere after 1995. The

Appellant stayed in Hong Kong with her spouse because she felt this was her role as “a traditional

Chinese wife.” She travel ed to Canada regularly until 2013 on her own. After 2013, her spouse’s

health deteriorated, and she could no longer leave him to travel to Canada. He died in Hong Kong

in September 2018. In April 2019, the [REDACTED]’s daughter had surgery in Hong Kong . In mid -

2019, the [REDACTED]’s son learned that the Appellant could apply for a PR travel document. At

that time, a proposed extradition bill caused protests and di...

compassionate considerations i will refer to paragraph 67 1 c of the act this paragraph states that an appeal is allowed if taking into account the best interests of a child directly affected by the decision sufficient humanitarian

overextraction_cases.case_text:
(CA IRB)

IAD File No. / No de dossier de la SAI : MC0 -05107

Client ID No. / No ID client : 90191623





1

ORAL REASONS FOR DECISION

[French version e dited for spelling, grammar and syntax]

OVERVIEW

[1] You, [REDACTED] , are the appellant. You are a citizen of Algeria and a permanent

resident of Canada.

[2] Permanent residents of Canada must comply with a residency obligation. One of the ways

to comply with it is to have spent a sufficient number of days in Canada.

[3] To be able to enter Canada, you applied for a permanent resident travel document. This

application was received by the Canadian immigration authorities on August 8, 2019 . An

immigration officer refused this application because he concluded that you had not complied with

your residency obligation. This is the decision being appealed before me. Your appeal is based on

subsection 63(4) of the Immigration and Refugee Protectio n Act , which I will refer to simply as the

Act.

[4] You admit that you did not comply with your residency obligation. However, you are

asking that you r appeal be allowed based on humanitarian and compassionate considerations. The

Minister’s representative is request ing that your appeal be dismissed.

[5] The standard of proof in this appeal is the balance of probabilities, requiring that

allegations are more likely than not to be true .

[6] I conclude that you failed to comply with your residency obligation. I also conclude that

there are not sufficient humanitarian and compassionate considerations. I will refer to

paragraph 67(1)(c) of the Act. This paragraph states that an appeal is allowed if, taking into

account the best interests of a child directly affected by the decision, sufficient humanitarian and

compassionate considerations warrant special relief in light of all the circumstances of the case.

[7] Given that I conclude that there are not sufficient humanitarian and compassionate

considerations, the appeal is d ismissed.

overextraction_cases.case_text:
(CA IRB)

IAD File No. / No de dossier de la SAI : TB0 -05377

Client ID No. / No ID client : 2059 -3671



1



REASONS FOR DECISION



INTRODUCTION



[1] [REDACTED] (the appellant) appeals the decision of the issuance of a removal

order made against him on April 9, 2 010 by a Minister’s Delegate. The appellant was found to

be a person described in section 41(b) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA ) for

failing to comply with his residency obligation as described in section 28 of IRPA.1



[2] The appellant i nitially disputed the Minister’s Delegate’s findings with respect to the

validity of the removal order ; however , later in the hearing he was prepared to concede the

validity issue. Instead, he asked that the panel allow the appeal given that , taking into account

the best interests of a child di rectly affected by the decision there are humanitarian and

compassionate grounds that warrant special consideration in light of all the circumstances in the

case.



ISSUES



[3] At issue is whether or not the removal or der issued agains t the appellant is valid in law;



[4] If the Removal Order is valid in law, taking into consideration a child directly affected by

the decision, whether there exist humanitarian and compassionate grounds that warrant special

relief, in light of all the circumstances in this case.



DECISION



[5] The removal order is valid in law;



[6] The panel finds that taking into consideration the best interest of a child directly affected

by the decision, there are sufficient humanitarian and compassionate ground s that warrant the



1 See Record, p. 1.

2013 CanLII 97572 (CA IRB)

IAD File No. / No de dossier de la SAI : TB0 -05377

Client ID No. / No ID client : 2059 -3671



2



granting of special relief in light of all the circumstances of this case. Accordingly, the appeal is

allowed and the removal order is set aside.



BACKGROUND



[7] The appellant testified that he was born in the United States...
